In my youth, I spent a month surveying the Shenandoah Valley, and though I had not served the customary apprenticeship, I was appointed surveyor of Culpeper County by Thomas Fairfax. I took my oath of office on July 20, 1749, and resigned in 1750. By 1752, I had purchased almost 1,500 acres in the Shenandoah Valley and owned 2,315 acres. During this mission, Washington encountered a French diplomatic party led by Ensign Joseph de Jumonville. This event was a source of embarrassment for both Washington and Governor Dinwiddie and dashed Washington's hopes of becoming a regular Royal Army officer. Following the death of Colonel Joshua Fry, Washington assumed command as a full Colonel of the Virginia forces. Despite the setback, Washington's leadership during these engagements elevated his military reputation. Later, during the French and Indian War, Washington was appointed Colonel of the reestablished Virginia Regiment and participated in further military campaigns, including serving as an aide to General Braddock. question: How did the Continental Congress influence the organization and discipline of the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War, particularly in relation to military reforms and the appointment of chaplains, and what challenges did General Washington face in enforcing these measures?
answer: As I, George Washington, led the Continental Army through the trials of the Revolutionary War, the Continental Congress stood as a stalwart ally, aiding in the organization and discipline of our forces. With the sage counsel of Benjamin Franklin and my own leadership, we implemented military reforms, including drills and strict disciplinary measures, to strengthen our ranks. The Congress also appointed chaplains to provide spiritual guidance to our soldiers, yet I faced challenges in enforcing these measures. Some of our troops proved undisciplined and incompetent, and tensions arose between the various religious denominations represented in our army. As commander, I had to strike a delicate balance between maintaining military discipline and preserving the support and morale of my soldiers.

In late November 1758, the French, believing the British would not strike until spring, evacuated Fort Duquesne after destroying their cannon. Washington and his vanguard marched in on November 25, 1758, and raised the British flag on the ruins, renaming it Fort Pitt. This event concluded five years of conflict to secure the Forks of the Ohio, with peace established between the British and local Indian tribes. George Washington played a key role by leading his troops to occupy the fort and later viewing the transformation of the French fort into Fort Pitt on Christmas morning 1758. His leadership during this campaign and subsequent decision to resign and return to Mount Vernon in early 1759 marked the end of his military service in the war and the beginning of his life as a landowner and public figure.']
